tossups.question: This figure’s Etruscan counterparts, often depicted with Vanth, swing hammers at Laris Pulenas’s head in a sarcophagus relief. Deadly vapors spill from this figure’s sacred cave of Aornum (“ah-OR-num”). Seneca relates how Hercules overpowered this figure with his own pole. In The Frogs, the slave Xanthias is forced to run around a lake by this figure, who discusses frog-swan songs with Dionysus. During his (*) katabasis, Aeneas pacified this child of Erebus and Nyx with a golden bough. An obol (“OH-bull”) placed in the mouth, rather than over the eyes, is given to this psychopomp of the Acheron (“AK-er-on”), who forces the unburied to wait 100 years before receiving transport. For 10 points, name this ferryman of the Styx who guides souls to Hades.
tossups.question_sanitized: This figure's Etruscan counterparts, often depicted with Vanth, swing hammers at Laris Pulenas's head in a sarcophagus relief. In The Frogs, the slave Xanthias is forced to run around a lake by this figure, who discusses frog-swan songs with Dionysus. During his (*) katabasis, Aeneas pacified this child of Erebus and Nyx with a golden bough. An obol ("OH-bull") placed in the mouth, rather than over the eyes, is given to this psychopomp of the Acheron ("AK-er-on"), who forces the unburied to wait 100 years before receiving transport. For 10 points, name this ferryman of the Styx who guides souls to Hades.
tossups.answer: Charon [or Kharon or Charos; accept Charun or Karu or Karun; accept Charonium; reject “Chiron” (“KAI-run”)] (Welcome to the underworld that is the PACE NSC.)
tossups.answer_sanitized: Charon [or Kharon or Charos; accept Charun or Karu or Karun; accept Charonium; reject "Chiron" ("KAI-run")] (Welcome to the underworld that is the PACE NSC.)

tossups.question: It’s not a rifle, but a “Winchester” object resembling this other object was used for one of the costumed jousting events named for it in Europe. A violent Yuletide quarrel led a Cornishman to create this portable object, over which loyalty oaths were sworn during the feast of Pentecost. This object is engraved with golden names by an archbishop’s blessing. A white deer is chased around this object by a hound during a royal wedding. (*) Judas’s betrayal is memorialized through this object’s Siege Perilous, which is claimed by Galahad before the start of the Grail quest. Leodegrance gifted this object, whose shape symbolized the equality of Arthur’s vassals. For 10 points, Lancelot was one of the many knights of what object?

tossups.question: One of these objects turns back time when reverting arrows to canebrakes and birds. A text named for one of these objects coined the maxim “as above, so below.” The Anzu steals one of these objects from a bathing Enlil, resulting in Ninurta being sent to retrieve it. During the war to avenge Abzu, this type of object acts as Kingu’s breastplate. The philosopher’s stone is described by (*) Hermes Trismegistus in an “Emerald” text named for this type of object. Marduk claims one of these objects of “destiny” after slaying Tiamat. The Epic of Gilgamesh was discovered on some of these objects taken from Ashurbanipal’s library. For 10 points, reed-pen styluses inscribed Mesopotamian myths on what clay writing medium?

tossups.question: Knives are placed in the mouths of this figure and a noble warrior princess to get a ruler to release the latter’s father in the subplot of a “Romance.” The thought of a potion that reforms “golden lotuses” comforts this figure, who later captures the bandit “Leopard Skin.” This figure comments on how the genders of two rabbits running side-by-side are indistinguishable after revealing (*) her combed hair adorned with golden flowers. The Khan gifts a camel to this figure during an eponymous ballad set during the Rouran invasion of the Northern Wèi. Because this figure lacks an elder brother, she replaces her father when answering a conscription notice. For 10 points, name this cross-dressing Chinese heroine.
tossups.question_sanitized: Knives are placed in the mouths of this figure and a noble warrior princess to get a ruler to release the latter's father in the subplot of a "Romance." This figure comments on how the genders of two rabbits running side-by-side are indistinguishable after revealing (*) her combed hair adorned with golden flowers. The Khan gifts a camel to this figure during an eponymous ballad set during the Rouran invasion of the Northern Wei. tossups.answer: Mùlán [or Huā Mùlán] (The works mentioned are the Romance of Sui and Tang, the Female Mulan, and the Ballad of Mulan.)

The golden doors and silver posts of Alcinous’s palace were guarded by two of these things. A Colchian princess gave a hero a magic ointment that he rubbed on to defeat some of these things. Poeas’s (“POI-ah’s”) arrow felled one of these things, bleeding golden ichor from its single vein. Jason yoked two of these things that could breathe fire and resembled (*) bulls. tossups.question: This figure names a cave system where Snorri Sturlson’s son was castrated and blinded, as related by the Sturlunga Saga. This figure will move from the south with the scourge of branches to arrive first at the field of Vigriðr (“VEE-gree-dor”). This figure will slay Beli’s bane, because the latter had given his sword to Skirnir. This wielder of a (*) “bright sword” will lead a giant army over the Bifrost which will crumble in their wake. Líf and Lífþrasir (“leef-THRA-seer”), the last of humanity, will hide in Hoddmímis holt to escape the devastation wrought by this slayer of Freyr at Ragnarok’s conclusion. For 10 points, name this guardian of Muspelheim, a giant destined to burn the Earth with flame.

For 10 points, name this guardian of Muspelheim, a giant destined to burn the Earth with flame.
tossups.answer: Surtr [or Surt] (The first line refers to the removal of one testicle and the blinding of one eye in Surtshellir.)

tossups.question: A race of “little people” in this region miraculously constructed roads and temples overnight for the price of one shrimp. In this region, mortals lacking a merciful ancestor must strip naked and lie motionless to avoid death upon sighting the nightmarchers. ’Alae (“uh-LAH-ay”) feathers sacred to Hina decorated an object used to create this region. This region’s snow goddess wins a sled race against a goddess who turned the dancer (*) Hopoe (“ho-PO-ay”) to stone after her sister Hi’iaka (“hee-ee-AH-kuh”) failed to return after 40 days. It’s not New Zealand, but a trickster demigod names an island he fished up in this archipelago, whose native deities include Pele (“PAY-lay”). For 10 points, name this archipelago whose islands include one named for Māui.

tossups.question: These creatures’ liver was mixed with egg-yolk to produce St. Hildegard’s leprosy-curing ointment. A bovine creature of this type is depicted alongside an “incense burner” or “sacred filter” on Indus seals. The re’em (“reh-em”) and the “Indian ass” of the Greeks were conflated with these creatures, which could purify water by making the sign of the cross. Hunters tied naked (*) virgins to trees in order to entrap these “lewd” creatures who were attracted to their purity. On a coat of arms, the lion is portrayed opposite to one of these goat-bearded creatures, which are Scotland’s national animal. European nobility mistook walrus and narwhal ivory for these creatures’ alicorns. For 10 points, name these single-horned horses.

tossups.answer: unicorns [or monoceros]

tossups.question: A god refuses entry to one of these figures at Mount Kailash, causing that figure to impatiently strike out with a weapon gifted to him by Shiva (“SHI-vuh”). Five lakes swell with the blood of the twenty-one warrior generations slain by one of these figures, who, in another myth, uses his axe to chop off Ganesha’s tusk. During the rasalila (“ra-sa-LEE-la”), one of these figures duplicates himself to dance with the (*) gopis (“GO-peas”) and Radha. Holi celebrates how a half-lion one of these figures burst from a pillar to save Prahlada (“pruh-huh-LAH-duh”). Arjuna learns about dharma from one of these figures who acts as his charioteer in the Bhagavad Gita. For 10 points, Parashurama (“puh-ruh-shoe-RAH-muh”) and Narasimha (“nuh-ruh-SIM-huh”) number among what ten incarnations of the Preserver, such as Krishna?

tossups.question: Alice Auma imparted this trait on the Holy Spirit Movement’s followers by enchanting their drinks to transform certain objects into water. General Butt-Naked stripped bare to obtain this trait during the Liberian Civil War. A child of Typhon who slew Molorchus’s son is revealed to have this trait after a hero strikes at its left flank, forcing that hero to corner it within a two-mouthed cave. Although Soumaoro Kante’s magic bestowed him this physical trait, it vanished at the Battle of (*) Kirina when he was struck by a white rooster spur shot by Sundiata. A Greek hero used a creature’s own claws to obtain a pelt with this trait. For 10 points, the Styx imparted what trait upon Achilles’s whole body, barring the heel?
tossups.question_sanitized: Alice Auma imparted this trait on the Holy Spirit Movement's followers by enchanting their drinks to transform certain objects into water. General Butt-Naked stripped bare to obtain this trait during the Liberian Civil War. A child of Typhon who slew Molorchus's son is revealed to have this trait after a hero strikes at its left flank, forcing that hero to corner it within a two-mouthed cave. Although Soumaoro Kante's magic bestowed him this physical trait, it vanished at the Battle of (*) Kirina when he was struck by a white rooster spur shot by Sundiata. A Greek hero used a creature's own claws to obtain a pelt with this trait. For 10 points, the Styx imparted what trait upon Achilles's whole body, barring the heel?
tossups.answer: invulnerability [or similar answers such as invincible; accept having impenetrable skin or pelt; accept being immune to bullets, spears, swords, and other weapons; reject “immortality”]
tossups.answer_sanitized: invulnerability [or similar answers such as invincible; accept having impenetrable skin or pelt; accept being immune to bullets, spears, swords, and other weapons; reject "immortality"]

tossups.question: The Zorya sisters watch over one of these animals restrained by an iron chain in the Little Dipper because its release portends the world’s end. In various Scandinavian tales, foreign rulers made these animals the kings of their defeated enemies. The red-eyed Shuck and Barghest are two of these animals that portend death within a year and are colored (*) black in British folklore. A hero with a geas (“gay-us”) is forced to break a taboo of eating this animal’s meat following a hag’s offer. Two of these animals were placed in the sky alongside Orion. Sétanta takes the name Cú Chulainn (“coo KULL-in”) after killing one of these animals. For 10 points, what animal is depicted by the constellation Canis Major?
tossups.question_sanitized: The Zorya sisters watch over one of these animals restrained by an iron chain in the Little Dipper because its release portends the world's end. In various Scandinavian tales, foreign rulers made these animals the kings of their defeated enemies. The red-eyed Shuck and Barghest are two of these animals that portend death within a year and are colored (*) black in British folklore. A hero with a geas ("gay-us") is forced to break a taboo of eating this animal's meat following a hag's offer. Two of these animals were placed in the sky alongside Orion. Setanta takes the name Cu Chulainn ("coo KULL-in") after killing one of these animals. For 10 points, what animal is depicted by the constellation Canis Major?
tossups.answer: dogs [accept dog kings; reject “wolf”]
tossups.answer_sanitized: dogs [accept dog kings; reject "wolf"]

tossups.question: A demoness residing in the sea captures this non-Chinese figure’s shadow, only to be torn apart from the inside after he enters her jaw. This figure respectfully touches a winged mountain after it rises from the sea to offer him respite during his flight. The size-changing jaws of a disguised Surasa (“sue-rah-SAH”), the mother of nagas (“NAH-guhs”), are unable to entrap this figure. The bear king Jambavan (“JAHM-buh-vun”) reminds this character of his divine powers, enabling this (*) vanara’s (“VAH-nuh-ruh’s”) ocean-spanning flight. This figure is blessed with immortality after he tears open his chest to reveal Rama (“RAH-muh”) and Sita’s (“SEE-thuh’s”) images upon his heart. This god delivers a mountain full of herbs to save Lakshmana’s (“LUCKSH-muh-nuh’s”) life. For 10 points, Ravana (“RAH-vuh-nuh”) sets ablaze the tail of what monkey god?
tossups.question_sanitized: A demoness residing in the sea captures this non-Chinese figure's shadow, only to be torn apart from the inside after he enters her jaw. This figure respectfully touches a winged mountain after it rises from the sea to offer him respite during his flight. The size-changing jaws of a disguised Surasa ("sue-rah-SAH"), the mother of nagas ("NAH-guhs"), are unable to entrap this figure. The bear king Jambavan ("JAHM-buh-vun") reminds this character of his divine powers, enabling this (*) vanara's ("VAH-nuh-ruh's") ocean-spanning flight. This figure is blessed with immortality after he tears open his chest to reveal Rama ("RAH-muh") and Sita's ("SEE-thuh's") images upon his heart. This god delivers a mountain full of herbs to save Lakshmana's ("LUCKSH-muh-nuh's") life. For 10 points, Ravana ("RAH-vuh-nuh") sets ablaze the tail of what monkey god?
tossups.answer: Hanuman (Simhika is the demoness in the first line.)
tossups.answer_sanitized: Hanuman (Simhika is the demoness in the first line.)

tossups.question: Description acceptable. A figure who assists with this event using her overwhelming strength arrives on a giant wolf using vipers as reins. During this event, a god restrains himself from smiting Hyrrokkin and later punts Litr into a fire. A father sets down the ring Draupnir during this event, where Nanna dies from grief before she’s burned on the ship (*) Ringhorn as it is cast into the sea. A god wins a wisdom contest by asking what was whispered into the ear of this event’s central participant. In the Gylfaginning, this event occurs directly before Hermóðr (“HAIR-mode”) arrives in Hel on Sleipnir, where he is given a task to make all things dead and alive weep. For 10 points, name this event that cremated a Norse god slain by mistletoe.
tossups.question_sanitized: Description acceptable. A figure who assists with this event using her overwhelming strength arrives on a giant wolf using vipers as reins. During this event, a god restrains himself from smiting Hyrrokkin and later punts Litr into a fire. A father sets down the ring Draupnir during this event, where Nanna dies from grief before she's burned on the ship (*) Ringhorn as it is cast into the sea. A god wins a wisdom contest by asking what was whispered into the ear of this event's central participant. In the Gylfaginning, this event occurs directly before Hermoðr ("HAIR-mode") arrives in Hel on Sleipnir, where he is given a task to make all things dead and alive weep. For 10 points, name this event that cremated a Norse god slain by mistletoe.
tossups.answer: funeral of Baldr [accept anything referring to the cremation of Baldr; prompt on answers referring to the death of Baldr]
tossups.answer_sanitized: funeral of Baldr [accept anything referring to the cremation of Baldr; prompt on answers referring to the death of Baldr]

tossups.question: In Theophilus’s account, this figure is cursed to be consumed by the children born from an incestuous relationship with Phalanx. A sprinkle of Hecate’s herb juice costs this figure’s hair, nose, and ears. This child of Idmon nearly dies by hanging after being beaten thrice on the head. A crone dramatically proclaims “She is here” when unmasking her divine visage in front of this boastful figure, who creates a (*) blasphemous work of art recalling how the gods transformed into animals to seduce women through trickery. In Ovid’s Metamorphoses, a shuttle is used to ruthlessly beat this woman, who had earlier challenged Minerva to a weaving contest. For 10 points, an enraged Athena transforms what woman into a spider?
tossups.question_sanitized: In Theophilus's account, this figure is cursed to be consumed by the children born from an incestuous relationship with Phalanx. A sprinkle of Hecate's herb juice costs this figure's hair, nose, and ears. This child of Idmon nearly dies by hanging after being beaten thrice on the head. A crone dramatically proclaims "She is here" when unmasking her divine visage in front of this boastful figure, who creates a (*) blasphemous work of art recalling how the gods transformed into animals to seduce women through trickery. In Ovid's Metamorphoses, a shuttle is used to ruthlessly beat this woman, who had earlier challenged Minerva to a weaving contest. For 10 points, an enraged Athena transforms what woman into a spider?
tossups.answer: Arachne
tossups.answer_sanitized: Arachne

tossups.question: Prior to this city’s founding, a king declared war on a people who used his daughter’s skin as a priest’s skirt. A 16th century CE pictographic map depicts the journey towards this city from a northern “place of herons” once settled by a people who emerged from seven caves. Copil’s heart marked this city’s location, directions to which were whispered by a hummingbird idol carried by priests. A god born from a ball of (*) feathers informed migrants where to perform this city’s 1325 CE founding. A god of war told one people to build this city where a snake-devouring eagle perched on a cactus. For 10 points, Nahuatl refugees settled what city on a swampy island in Lake Texcoco, the future Aztec capital?
tossups.question_sanitized: Prior to this city's founding, a king declared war on a people who used his daughter's skin as a priest's skirt. A 16th century CE pictographic map depicts the journey towards this city from a northern "place of herons" once settled by a people who emerged from seven caves. Copil's heart marked this city's location, directions to which were whispered by a hummingbird idol carried by priests. A god born from a ball of (*) feathers informed migrants where to perform this city's 1325 CE founding. A god of war told one people to build this city where a snake-devouring eagle perched on a cactus. For 10 points, Nahuatl refugees settled what city on a swampy island in Lake Texcoco, the future Aztec capital?
tossups.answer: Tenochtitlan [accept Mexico City] (The northern “place of herons” is the Aztec homeland of Aztlan; the map is the Siguenza map.)
tossups.answer_sanitized: Tenochtitlan [accept Mexico City] (The northern "place of herons" is the Aztec homeland of Aztlan; the map is the Siguenza map.)

tossups.question: Two answers required. Poseidon guarantees a debt on a crime committed by these two deities after he is told that “pledges for trustless folk are trustless pledges.” In the Odyssey, Demodocus tells of how another god feigned travel to Lemnos to later surprise these two deities. Alectryon is turned into a rooster after his failure to keep watch causes Helios to discover these two deities. The gods laugh at the irony of a slow god catching a swift one upon discovering these two deities. (*) Harmonia, Phobos, and Deimos are born to these two deities, who are ensnared in an unbreakable net by a crippled god. For 10 points, Hephaestus is betrayed by an affair between what brother and wife of his, the deities of war and love?
tossups.question_sanitized: Two answers required. Poseidon guarantees a debt on a crime committed by these two deities after he is told that "pledges for trustless folk are trustless pledges." In the Odyssey, Demodocus tells of how another god feigned travel to Lemnos to later surprise these two deities. Alectryon is turned into a rooster after his failure to keep watch causes Helios to discover these two deities. The gods laugh at the irony of a slow god catching a swift one upon discovering these two deities. (*) Harmonia, Phobos, and Deimos are born to these two deities, who are ensnared in an unbreakable net by a crippled god. For 10 points, Hephaestus is betrayed by an affair between what brother and wife of his, the deities of war and love?
tossups.answer: Aphrodite AND Ares [accept in any order; accept Mars AND Venus; accept Kythereia and Cypris in place of Aphrodite]
tossups.answer_sanitized: Aphrodite AND Ares [accept in any order; accept Mars AND Venus; accept Kythereia and Cypris in place of Aphrodite]

tossups.question: Henry Louis Gates Jr. writes the practice of “signifyin’ ” derives from this culture’s trickster archetype. An anthropologist collected stories told in this culture’s vernacular in Mules and Men. A hero from this culture dies after defeating a mechanical drill in a race to create a railroad tunnel. Joel Chandler Harris collected many stories based on this culture’s folklore featuring (*) Uncle Remus and Brer Rabbit. John Henry is a hero from this culture’s folklore. For 10 points, name this culture, much of whose folklore developed after coming to America as slaves.
tossups.question_sanitized: Henry Louis Gates Jr. writes the practice of "signifyin' " derives from this culture's trickster archetype. An anthropologist collected stories told in this culture's vernacular in Mules and Men. A hero from this culture dies after defeating a mechanical drill in a race to create a railroad tunnel. Joel Chandler Harris collected many stories based on this culture's folklore featuring (*) Uncle Remus and Brer Rabbit. John Henry is a hero from this culture's folklore. For 10 points, name this culture, much of whose folklore developed after coming to America as slaves.
tossups.answer: African-American culture [or Black American culture; accept African culture or Black culture; prompt on American culture or US culture before “America”; accept “mythology” or “folklore” or “stories” in place of “culture;”prompt on formerly enslaved people or Black slaves or African slaves]
tossups.answer_sanitized: African-American culture [or Black American culture; accept African culture or Black culture; prompt on American culture or US culture before "America"; accept "mythology" or "folklore" or "stories" in place of "culture;"prompt on formerly enslaved people or Black slaves or African slaves]

tossups.question: One of these creatures titles Marie de France’s lai “Bisclavret.” A belief in how to kill these creatures dates to Jean Chastel’s method of killing the Beast of Gévaudan. Juice from purple aconite flowers were dripped on arrows to hunt these creatures, leading to its nickname as a (*) “bane.” A term for these creatures originates from a Spartan king who was punished by Zeus for eating his own son. These creatures could be spotted from curved fingernails or cutting the flesh to reveal fur. These sufferers of lycanthropy could be hunted using silver bullets. For 10 points, name these creatures who transform from human to canine under a full moon.
tossups.question_sanitized: One of these creatures titles Marie de France's lai "Bisclavret." A belief in how to kill these creatures dates to Jean Chastel's method of killing the Beast of Gevaudan. Juice from purple aconite flowers were dripped on arrows to hunt these creatures, leading to its nickname as a (*) "bane." A term for these creatures originates from a Spartan king who was punished by Zeus for eating his own son. These creatures could be spotted from curved fingernails or cutting the flesh to reveal fur. These sufferers of lycanthropy could be hunted using silver bullets. For 10 points, name these creatures who transform from human to canine under a full moon.
tossups.answer: werewolf [accept lycanthropes or lycans until “lycanthropy”; prompt on wolf or wolfsbane]
tossups.answer_sanitized: werewolf [accept lycanthropes or lycans until "lycanthropy"; prompt on wolf or wolfsbane]

tossups.question: A woman complaining to this person about her husband says “He is all fault who hath no fault at all.” This person conquered and moved into the Dolorous Gard, renaming it “Joyous Gard.” This person rescues his lover from the evil Maleagant in Chrétien de Troyes’s (“creh-tee-ANN duh TWAHZ”) Knight of the Cart. (*) Elaine of Corbenic uses a ring to trick this person into fathering a man destined to find the Holy Grail. This person is the father of Sir Galahad. For 10 points, name this Knight of the Round Table who had an affair with Queen Guinevere and was the closest friend of King Arthur.
tossups.question_sanitized: A woman complaining to this person about her husband says "He is all fault who hath no fault at all." This person conquered and moved into the Dolorous Gard, renaming it "Joyous Gard." This person rescues his lover from the evil Maleagant in Chretien de Troyes's ("creh-tee-ANN duh TWAHZ") Knight of the Cart. (*) Elaine of Corbenic uses a ring to trick this person into fathering a man destined to find the Holy Grail. This person is the father of Sir Galahad. For 10 points, name this Knight of the Round Table who had an affair with Queen Guinevere and was the closest friend of King Arthur.
tossups.answer: Lancelot [or Sir Lancelot du Lac]
tossups.answer_sanitized: Lancelot [or Sir Lancelot du Lac]
